description:
Some background: @sacielo had some FLASH datasets where he had a custom units implementation, which does not jibe with our "cgs-only" assumption in the FLASH frontend.

The Athena frontend already allows for the user to supply code units in a dictionary passed to `load`, like so:


```
#!python

import yt

parameters={"time_unit":(1.0,"Myr"),
            "length_unit":(1.0,"Mpc"),
            "mass_unit":(1.0e14,"Msun")}

ds = yt.load("virgo_novisc.0054.vtk", parameters=parameters)

```

This PR extends this functionality to the other frontends, allowing the user to specify their own code units (thus overriding the defaults) using an `units_override` dictionary, which does the same thing as the Athena example above. This, of course, is risky business, but a feature that I think some users (at least one!) would want. 

Why this is WIP:

1) Needs documentation  
2) Needs tests  
3) Needs to be added to other frontends  

I'm setting up the PR now so that folks can comment and suggest changes before I go through and start setting it up everywhere. 

In the course of testing this I added some new magnetic-related fields.

UPDATE: Documentation and tests have been added, and the functionality has been added to all the frontends that make sense. I had to make some small changes to the RAMSES and the MOAB frontends--someone who knows these should check them. 

UPDATE 2: The fact that we cache datasets automatically led to some issues in the test I developed where I have to load a dataset twice, so I developed a configuration option that turns caching on and off (which is set by default to False). I'm guessing it could have other applications. 

UPDATE 3: Addressed @MatthewTurk and @ngoldbaum's comments.
title: [APICHANGE] Overriding code units

content.raw: Right now yt assumes a constant gamma internally in many places. This is definitely something that we need to look into and is related to your concerns about the relationship between internal energy and thermal energy.
content.html: Right now yt assumes a constant gamma internally in many places. This is definitely something that we need to look into and is related to your concerns about the relationship between internal energy and thermal energy.

content.raw: Would anything break if this were `True` by default?
content.html: Would anything break if this were True by default?

content.raw: I don't know, but I'm guessing that we'd need a consensus to make that the default behavior.
content.html: I don't know, but I'm guessing that we'd need a consensus to make that the default behavior.

content.raw: So are all tests now actually, really, truly passing?
content.html: So are all tests now actually, really, truly passing?

content.raw: I think it would break unpickling of data objects, which is very very rarely done, I believe.  I'd like to get to the point where this can safely be `False`, but keep in mind that this also enables, for instance, a per-instance cache of which datasets are currently loaded (not which have been loaded) so it will get flushed if the ds object is properly GC'd first.
content.html: I think it would break unpickling of data objects, which is very very rarely done, I believe. I'd like to get to the point where this can safely be False, but keep in mind that this also enables, for instance, a per-instance cache of which datasets are currently loaded (not which have been loaded) so it will get flushed if the ds object is properly GC'd first.

content.html: This probably doesn't need to be in an else block.

content.raw: Does `units_override` need to be in the `Dataset` API for the SPH frontends?
content.html: Does units_override need to be in the Dataset API for the SPH frontends?

content.raw: Besides the minor comment regarding the SPH frontends, LGTM.
content.html: Besides the minor comment regarding the SPH frontends, LGTM.

content.raw: Its inclusion here was mainly for consistency, and so that if someone tries to use it they will at least see some kind of response, but if you like we can remove it.
content.html: Its inclusion here was mainly for consistency, and so that if someone tries to use it they will at least see some kind of response, but if you like we can remove it.

content.raw: To put it more clearly, I don't think it should go by silently if someone tries to use it--they ought to at least know that nothing is happening, and what they should do instead.
content.html: To put it more clearly, I don't think it should go by silently if someone tries to use it--they ought to at least know that nothing is happening, and what they should do instead.

content.raw:
OK, but I think issuing a warning and ignoring `units_override` might not be the best way to handle this.

What about either raising a RuntimeError using the text of the warning or copying the contents of units_override over to the unit_base dict?
content.html:
OK, but I think issuing a warning and ignoring units_override might not be the best way to handle this.
